title: Where does the last name Flanagan come from in Ireland? - Quora

response.answer_text: There were at least three separate and unrelated Irish clans named Ó Flannagáin, and many people bear the name in Scotland as well. Ó Flannagáins could be found originally in Roscommon in the West, Monaghan and Fermanagh in the North, and Offaly in the East. In Scotland they were originally in Fife in East Central Scotland, in Ayrshire in the Southwest, in Perthshire right in the middle, and in Berwickshire in the extreme Southeast. Since flann means ‘red’ or ‘ruddy’, and since redheads are about 10% of the Irish population and 6% of the Scottish population, it’s hardly surprising that it should be a popular source of names. My own surname Cowan is from Mac Eoghain, but there is no reason to think that I am related to all other Cowans: Eoghan, though originally a pagan name meaning ‘born from the yew’, is popular throughout the Celtic lands as Ewen, Owen, Owain (in Wales), and even John in Co. Mayo, where my people come from (probably by confusion with Eóin, the Irish version of the various biblical persons named John in English). So here I am, born from the yew, ancestrally from the Plain of the Yews (Maigh Eo, Mayo), living in the New Place of the Yews (York in England was originally Eboracum in Latin, from a Common Brittonic word meaning ‘place of yew trees’). But I have never seen a living specimen of Taxus baccata in my life.
It’s pretty much all over Ireland as you can see at flanagan in Ireland.
